body_text.text: Bottomonium, a bound system of a bb quark-antiquark pair, is well described by nonrelativistic quantum mechanics due to the slow motion of the heavy quarks [1]. The spin-singlet (S = 0) states of the quark pair with zero orbital momentum, L = 0, are customarily called η b (nS) with n = 1, 2, . . .. The hyperfine splitting ∆M HF from the corresponding spin-triplet state, i.e. the mass difference between the Υ(nS) and η b (nS), provides an important measure of the spin-spin interaction between the quark and the antiquark. The existing measurements [2] of the η b (1S) mass are only in marginal agreement with theoretical expectations [3,4]
and the η b (1S)
width is yet to be measured. There is no information available on the radially excited state η b (2S).

In this Letter, we report the first evidence for the η b (2S) in the h b (2P ) → η b (2S)γ transition and the first observation of the h b (1P ) → η b (1S)γ and h b (2P ) → η b (1S)γ transitions. We use a 121.4 fb −1 data sample at the Υ(5S) resonance and 12.0 fb −1 of energy-scan data collected nearby with the Belle detector [5] at the KEKB asymmetric-energy e + e − collider [6].

We study the processes e + e − → Υ(5S) → h b (nP )π + π − → [η b (mS)γ]π + π − in which the η b (mS) states are reconstructed inclusively. To suppress continuum e + e − → qq (q = u, d, s, c) background, we use the ratio R 2 of the second-to zeroth-order Fox-Wolfram moments [9]. In the η b (1S) analysis, we require R 2 < 0.3, which was optimized using the Υ(5S) → Υ(2S)π + π − decays [7]. For the high statistics h b (1P ) → η b (1S)γ transition, the optimum is shifted to R 2 < 0.32, which we adopt here for the η b (2S) analysis.
